title: Social media a danger to relationships
text:
Social media a danger to relationships Generation gap: Some children are unimpressed by their parents’ online behaviour. — 123rf.com 
’S the thing; many parents do not approve of their children’s behaviour online. According to Kaspersky Lab’s Digital Lives study, the feeling is mutual. 
“compromising circumstances” category are photos taken while under the influence of alcohol, or while wearing revealing clothes or nudity, among others. 
’s online behaviour, while 16% of them admitted that their relationship with their spouse or partners has been damaged due to their unfavourable social media antics. 
Today, digital communication complements real-life communication. We live in a globalised and highly mobile world resulting in distances between partners and family members,” said University of Wurzburg, Germany media psychologist Dr Astrid Carolus in a press statement. 
any of the respondents believe that the quality of their relationships has not suffered and is perhaps even better as a result of being connected online. 
Under certain circumstances, they perceive their online communication as ‘hyper-personal communication’ and thus they can misread and over-interpret the message on social media. We feel especially close, we blind out the rather negative, focus on the possible positive intentions behind a message and over interpret.” 
’t always make people happy. It can strain relationships as well as leave people feeling down and upset, as they constantly compare their lives to those of others. Almost 57% of them admitted that they feel terrible after going on social media. 
“likes” and social validation also leads people to increasingly share their private information on social media platforms, putting not only themselves but also their friends, family and colleagues at risk. The research shows that at least 37% of them share their home town, 31% share their e-mail address, 30% share their relationship status, 18% share details of their place of work and 14% share their address. 
Digital communication is an opportunity to bridge the gaps in our modern lives caused by living in different cities or countries,” said Carolus. “However, digital communication cannot replace face-to-face communication – at least not always and not completely.”
